details.title: BDD-based reliability analysis of phased-mission systems with multimode failures
details.standardTitle: BDD-based reliability analysis of phased-mission systems with multimode failures

p: Zhihua Tang received the B. S. degree (1996) in applied physics from Northeastern University, Shenyang, China; the M.S. degree (1999) in computer science from Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Science, Shenyang, China; and the M.S. degree (2002) in electrical engineering from the University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA.

He is now working toward the Ph.D. degree in the Charles L. Brown Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Virginia. His interests focus on reliability analysis of systems with dependent failures. He is a student member of IEEE.

authors.affiliation: Charles L. Brown Dept. of Electr. & Comput. Eng., Virginia Univ., Charlottesville, VA, USA
authors.name: Zhihua Tang

p: Joanne Bechta Dugan (F'00) received the B.A. degree in Mathematics and Computer Science from La Salle University, Philadelphia, PA in 1980; and the M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Electrical Engineering from Duke University, Durham, NC in 1982, and 1984, respectively.

She is currently Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering at the University of Virginia. She has performed and directed research on the development and application of techniques for the analysis of computer systems which are designed to tolerate hardware and software faults. Her research interests thus include hardware and software reliability engineering, fault tolerant computing, and mathematical modeling using dynamic fault trees, Markov models, Petri nets, and simulation.

Dr. Dugan is an IEEE Fellow, was Associate Editor of the IEEE Transactions on Reliability for 10 years, and was recently Associate Editor of the IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering. She served on the National Research Council Committee on Application of Digital Instrumentation and Control Systems to Nuclear Power Plant Operations and Safety.

authors.affiliation: Charles L. Brown Dept. of Electr. & Comput. Eng., Virginia Univ., Charlottesville, VA, USA
authors.name: J.B. Dugan

details.abstract: This paper proposes a new algorithm (DEP-BDD) based on binary decision diagram (BDD) for reliability analysis of phased-mission systems (PMS) with multimode failures. DEP-BDD is a BDD-based combinatorial model which can be used to deal with more than one kind of dependences by applying dependence algebra, which is a generalization of phase algebra that handles more complex dependences. The nature of the BDD contributes the efficiency and low computational complexity of this algorithm. Two examples are analysed to illustrate the applications and advantages of our approach.

context.text: Another PMS example is the ion propulsion system [1] used in a deep-space spacecraft mission, whose typical operating phases include launching, ascending, orbiting, reentry, descending, and landing.
As in the ion propulsion system example [1], each thruster assembly has one propulsion power unit (PPU), and two ion engines.
In the ion propulsion system [1], a typical thruster assembly consists of a PPU \$(P)\$, two ion engines (\$A\$ and \$B\$), and two propellant valves (\$V\$ and \$W\$), as shown in Fig. 6.

references.title: Next generation ion engines: mission performances
references.text: M. Noca, "Next generation ion engines: mission performances", 28th Int. Electric Propulsion Conf. 2003, 2003-March-1721.

links.abstract: A method for automated analysis of phased mission reliability which considers the problem in terms of the construction of a continuous-time discrete-state Markov model and uses a standard Markov-chain solution technique that is adapted to the problem of phased missions is presented. The resulting state space is the union of the states in each independent phase, rather than the sum. This results in a model that can be substantially smaller than those required by other methods. A unified framework...

context.text: Some researchers focus on solving the dependence across the phases using state-based approaches, which are based on Markov models or Petri nets [2]–[6].

references.title: Automated analysis of phased-mission reliability
references.text: J. B. Dugan, "Automated analysis of phased-mission reliability", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 40, pp. 45-52, 1991.

links.abstract: Three assumptions of Markov modeling for reliability of phased-mission systems that limit flexibility of representation are identified. The proposed generalization has the ability to represent state-dependent behavior, handle phases of random duration using globally time-dependent distributions of phase change time, and model globally time-dependent failure and repair rates. The approach is based on a single nonhomogeneous Markov model in which the concept of state transition is extended to incl...

links.abstract: The authors show how to determine the reliability of a multi-phase mission system whose configuration changes during consecutive time periods, assuming failure and repair times of components are exponentially distributed and redundant components are repairable as long as the system is operational. The mission reliability is obtained for 3 cases, based on a Markov model. (1) Phase durations are deterministic; the computational compact set model is formulated and a programmable solution is develop...

references.text: K. Kim, K. S. Park, "Phased-mission system reliability under Markov environment", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 43, pp. 301-309, 1994.

links.abstract: We focus on analytical modeling for the dependability evaluation of phased-mission systems. Because of their dynamic behavior, systems showing a phased behavior offer challenges in modeling. We propose the modeling and evaluation of phased-mission system dependability through the Deterministic and Stochastic Petri Nets (DSPN). The DSPN approach to the phased-mission systems offers many advantages, concerning both the modeling and the solution. The DSPN model of the mission can be a very concise ...

modeling and evaluation of phased mission systems: a DSPN approach

links.abstract: Multiple-Phased Systems (MPS), i.e., systems whose operational life can be partitioned in a set of disjoint periods, called "phases", include several classes of systems such as Phased Mission Systems and Scheduled Maintenance Systems. Because of their deployment in critical applications, the dependability modeling and analysis of Multiple-Phased Systems is a task of primary relevance. The phased behavior makes the analysis of Multiple-Phased Systems extremely complex. This paper describes the mo...

context.text: With efforts to deal with the state explosion problem in state-based approaches, researchers proposed another family of approaches based on combinatorial models [7]–[10], which exploit the low computational complexity and less storage space consumption in BDD manipulation.

The phase algebra applied to the variables that belong to the same component is listed in Table I [7]. \$C_{i}\ (\overline{C}_{i})\$ represents the event that component \$C\$ fails (is operational) in phase \$i\$. \$C_{j}\ (\overline{C}_{j})\$ represents the event that component \$C\$ fails (is operational) in phase \$j\$.

references.title:
An
algorithm for reliability analysis of phased-mission systems
references.text: Y. Ma, K. S. Trivedi, "An algorithm for reliability analysis of phased-mission systems", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 66, no. 2, pp. 157-170, 1999.

links.abstract: This paper presents a new algorithm (PMS-BDD) based on the binary decision diagram (BDD) for reliability analysis of phased-mission systems (PMS). PMS-BDD uses phase algebra to deal with the dependence across the phases, and a new BDD operation to incorporate the phase algebra. Due to the nature of the BDD, cancellation of common components among the phases can be combined with the BDD generation, without additional operations; and the sum of disjoint products (SDP) can be implicitly represented...

context.text: With efforts to deal with the state explosion problem in state-based approaches, researchers proposed another family of approaches based on combinatorial models [7]–[9][10], which exploit the low computational complexity and less storage space consumption in BDD manipulation.
[9] introduces a BDD-based method for PMS reliability analysis.

For example, the PMS-BDD generated by using backward PDO (phase dependent operation) [9] has the following properties:
1)
Any two variables connected by a 0-edge always belong to different components.

2)
The two variables connected by a 1-edge can belong to different components or the same component.

The ordering strategies (forward PDO, and backward PDO) presented in [9] must abide the following two rules:
3)
Orderings adopted in the generation of each single-phase BDD are consistent or the same for all the phases.

4)
Orderings of variables that belong to the same component but to different phases stay together.
The mini-component is a kind of conceptual structure used to deal with \$s\$-dependence across the phases of a given component [9], [26].
There are two classes of phase ordering: forward PDO, and backward PDO [9].
[9] shows that the size of the BDD generated by backward PDO is smaller than that generated by forward PDO.
Fig. 10 shows the PMS fault tree of an example in [9].
System configuration of a PMS example in [9].
System configuration of a PMS example in [9].

BDD-based algorithm for reliability evaluation of phased mission systems
references.text: X. Zang, H. Sun, K. S. Trivedi, "A BDD-based algorithm for reliability evaluation of phased mission systems", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 48, pp. 50-60, 1999.

links.abstract: This paper proposes a generalized phased-mission system (GPMS) analysis methodology called GPMS-CPR that has high computation efficiency and is easy to implement. GPMS-CPR can evaluate a wider range of more practical systems with less restrictive mission requirements, while offering more human-friendly performance indices such as multilevel grading as compared to the previous PMS approaches. GPMS-CPR also accounts for imperfect coverage. This method implements an exciting synthesis of several ap...

context.text: With efforts to deal with the state explosion problem in state-based approaches, researchers proposed another family of approaches based on combinatorial models [7]–[10], which exploit the low computational complexity and less storage space consumption in BDD manipulation.
The ongoing related research includes the analysis of PMS with imperfect coverage model (IPCM) [10]–[12], and the analysis of PMS with common cause failure [13], [14].
This advantage is considerably mitigated in [10], [19], and [25], where multistate BDD (MBDD) is used to manipulate the Boolean functions of multistate variables.

[10] generalizes the PDO and phase algebra to deal with the generalized phase mission systems with imperfect coverage model. [25] investigates the application of the multistate concept in evaluation of systems with an imperfect coverage model.
This example can also be analysed by using SEA (simple and efficient algorithm) based method presented in [10].

Due to the dynamic behavior & the statistical dependencies, generalized phased-mission systems offer big challenges in reliability modeling & analysis. A new family of decision diagrams called ternary decision diagrams (TDD) is proposed for use in the resulting separable approach to the GPMS reliability evaluation. Compared with existing methods, the accuracy of ...

diagram based analysis of generalized phased-mission reliability
references.text: L. Xing, J. B. Dugan, "A separable ternary decision diagram based analysis of generalized phased-mission reliability", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 53, pp. 174-184, June 2004.

links.abstract: This paper proposes efficient methods to assess the reliability of phased-mission systems (PMS) considering both imperfect fault coverage (IPC), and common-cause failures (CCF). The IPC introduces multimode failures that must be considered in the accurate reliability analysis of PMS. Another difficulty in analysis is to allow for multiple CCF that can affect different subsets of system components, and which can occur s-dependently. Our methodology for resolving the above difficulties is to separ...

context.text: The ongoing related research includes the analysis of PMS with imperfect coverage model (IPCM) [10]–[12], and the analysis of PMS with common cause failure [13], [14].

common-cause failures
references.text: L. Xing, "Phased-mission reliability and safety in the presence of common-cause failures", Proc. of the 21st Int. System Safety Conf. (ISSC'2003), 2003-August.

links.abstract: This paper proposes an efficient approach for incorporating CCF in the reliability analysis of phased-mission systems. The proposed approach is based on the implicit CCF analysis method and is illustrated through the analysis of an example PMS. In PMS analysis, a binary decision diagram (BDD) based method is used, which applies phase algebra. During the traversal of a PMS-BDD, our approach correctly includes the effect of CCF, dealing with the phase dependent failures at the same time. Basing ou...

context.text: The ongoing related research includes the analysis of PMS with imperfect coverage model (IPCM) [10]–[12], and the analysis of PMS with common cause failure [13], [14].

context.text: Multimode failure theory has been studied since 1975 [15], and many approaches have been proposed.

references.title: Fundamental concepts and relations for reliability analysis of multistate systems
references.text: J. D. Murchland, "Fundamental concepts and relations for reliability analysis of multistate systems" in Reliability and Fault Tree Analysis Theoretical and Applied Aspects of System Reliability, pp. 581-618, 1975, SIAM.

links.abstract: Discrete function theory, which extends switching function theory and multiple-valued logic function theory, is introduced into multistate system analysis. Some theoretical conclusions and algorithms which play key roles in multistate system analysis are presented. The concepts of s-coherence and duality in binary-state system analysis are generalized. The set of minimal upper (maximum lower) vectors for level j, which play the role of min path (cut) set, is introduced to represent the states of...

context.text: As in the analysis of PMS, either Markov models or combinatorial models can be used in multimode failure modeling and analysis [16]–[19].

references.title: On multistate system analysis
references.text: J. Xue, "On multistate system analysis", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. R-34, pp. 329-337, Oct. 1985.

links.abstract: The need for the combined performance and reliability analysis of fault tolerant systems is increasing. The common approach to formulating and solving such problems is to use (semi-)Markov reward models. However, the large size of state spaces is a problem that plagues Markovian models. Combinatorial models have been used for modeling reliability and availability of complex systems without paying the price of large Markov models. However, assumptions of two-state behavior of components (and that...

context.text: As in the analysis of PMS, either Markov models or combinatorial models can be used in multimode failure modeling and analysis [16]–[17][19].
This method is later evolved into a factoring solution [24], and an inclusion-exclusion method [17].

references.title:
Combinatorial algorithm for performance
and reliability analysis using multistate models
references.text: M. Veeraraghavan, K. S. Trivedi, "Combinatorial algorithm for performance and reliability analysis using multistate models", IEEE Trans. Computers, vol. 43, no. 2, pp. 229-234, 1994.

links.abstract: This paper generalizes 2-state (binary-state) reliability parameters 'R(t), F(t), /spl lambda/(t), and mean-time to-failure' to multi-state reliability parameters 'R(t,i), G(t,i), /spl lambda/(t,i), mean-life-span-at-specified-performance-level(i), for each state'. By using these generalized reliability parameters, multi-state reliability dynamic analysis can be transformed to a set of 2-state reliability dynamic analyses. Then, the authors extend some theoretical results in 2-state reliability ...

context.text: As in the analysis of PMS, either Markov models or combinatorial models can be used in multimode failure modeling and analysis [16]–[18][19].

references.title: Dynamic reliability analysis of coherent multi-state systems
references.text: J. Xue, K. Yang, "Dynamic reliability analysis of coherent multi-state systems", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 44, pp. 683-688, Dec. 1995.

links.abstract: A new algorithm based on binary decision diagram (BDD) for the analysis of a system with multistate components is proposed. Each state of a multistate component is represented by a boolean variable, and a multistate system is represented by a series of multistate fault trees. A Boolean algebra with restrictions on variables is used to address the dependence among these boolean variables that collectively represent the same component and a new BDD operation is proposed to realize this Boolean alg...

context.text: As in the analysis of PMS, either Markov models or combinatorial models can be used in multimode failure modeling and analysis [16]–[19].
This advantage is considerably mitigated in [10], [19], and [25], where multistate BDD (MBDD) is used to manipulate the Boolean functions of multistate variables.

[19] proposes multistate dependent operation (MDO) to analyse systems with multistate components. [10] generalizes the PDO and phase algebra to deal with the generalized phase mission systems with imperfect coverage model. [25] investigates the application of the multistate concept in evaluation of systems with an imperfect coverage model.

references.title:
A
BDD-based algorithm for analysis of multistate systems with multistate components
references.text: X. Zang, D. Wang, H. Sun, K. S. Trivedi, "A BDD-based algorithm for analysis of multistate systems with multistate components", IEEE Trans. Computers, vol. 52, no. 12, pp. 1608-1618, 2003.

links.abstract: In this paper we present a new data structure for representing Boolean functions and an associated set of manipulation algorithms. Functions are represented by directed, acyclic graphs in a manner similar to the representations introduced by Lee [1] and Akers [2], but with further restrictions on the ordering of decision variables in the graph. Although a function requires, in the worst case, a graph of size exponential in the number of arguments, many of the functions encountered in typical app...

context.text: A BDD [20] is a directed acyclic graph (DAG) that is based on Shannon decomposition theory [21].
For more details on BDD manipulation and evaluation, please refer to [20], [22].
Previous studies have shown that the problem of computing an optimized variable ordering for a BDD is a co NP-complete problem, and heuristics can be used to find a reasonable ordering [20].

references.title:
Graph based algorithms for Boolean function
manipulation
references.text: R. Bryant, "Graph based algorithms for Boolean function manipulation", IEEE Trans. Computers, vol. C-35, no. 8, pp. 677-691, 1986.

links.abstract: In the control and protective circuits of complex electrical systems it is frequently necessary to make intricate interconnections of relay contacts and switches. Examples of these circuits occur in automatic telephone exchanges, industrial motor-control equipment, and in almost any circuits designed to perform complex operations automatically. In this article a mathematical analysis of certain of the properties of such networks will be made. Particular attention will be given to the problem of ...

context.text: A Boolean algebra-based method for multistate system analysis was first proposed by Caldarola in [23].

references.title: Coherent systems with multistate components
references.text: L. Caldarola, "Coherent systems with multistate components", Nuclear Engineering and Design, vol. 58, pp. 127-139, 1980.

links.abstract: This paper shows how to model a multistate system with multistate components using binary variables. This modeling technique allows current binary algorithms for block diagrams and fault trees to be applied to multistate systems. Several multistate examples are presented, and some cases in which computational efficiency can be enhanced are discussed.

context.text: This method is later evolved into a factoring solution [24], and an inclusion-exclusion method [17].

references.title: Multistate block diagrams and fault trees
references.text: A. P. Wood, "Multistate block diagrams and fault trees", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. R-34, pp. 236-240, 1985.

links.abstract: In this paper a new algorithm based on Binary Decision Diagrams (BDD) for dependability analysis of distributed computer systems (DCS) with imperfect coverage is proposed. Minimum file spanning trees (MFST) are generated and stored via BDD manipulation. By using the multistate concept, our algorithm can generate BDDs that can deal with imperfect coverage and obtain reliability expressions from these BDDs. Ordering strategies for variables are discussed in this paper as well. Due to the nature of...
